awd_titl_txt: ICE-T: RI: Multi-Element Mobile Visible Light Communication for Smart Cities
awd_abstract_narration:
Prospective demands of next-generation wireless networks are ambitious and are projected to require cellular networks that support 1000 times higher data rates and 10 times lower round-trip latency. Visible light communication (VLC) is a promising technology to address the spectrum deficit problem in the legacy radio frequency bands. VLC technology can offer high speed data rates that can meet the exponential increase of wireless communications devices due to large modulation bandwidth of the Light Emitting Diodes (LEDs). Further, it can use the existing lighting infrastructure which may contain large number of LEDs for illumination, and therefore, it is cheaper than setting up new RF base stations.

This project seeks to design a multi-element mobile VLC architecture that is able to simultaneously transmit multiple data streams to multiple mobile users while keeping the uniformity of illumination across a room. The project explores a novel framework by designing the multi-element architecture as a hemispherical bulb consisting of multiple LEDs.  The intellectual merit of this project is to investigate and develop a multi-element VLC architecture that facilitates joint and adaptive optimization of two conflicting goals: illumination quality and mobile wireless communication. The proposed approach's significance comes from its aim to explore designs of software-defined multi-element modules with (a) narrow-angle transmitters LEDs for high spatial reuse and high aggregate throughput and (b) software protocols performing electronic steering of light beams to support mobility. Novel aspects of this activity are (i) joint optimization of mobile aggregate throughput and illumination uniformity in a multi-element VLC architecture using LEDs with narrow divergence angles; (ii) approximation and heuristic algorithms for optimizing transmit power of LEDs and LED-user associations in order to maximize the aggregate mobile user spectral efficiency via higher spatial reuse while taking into account a certain illumination quality; and (iii) experimentation of multi-element VLC concepts in a smart city testbed in Europe. The project initiates a collaboration between Investigators at the University of Central Florida and Northumbria University in the United Kingdom.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Visible Light Communication (VLC) is an emerging technology with significant potential to provide complementary wireless access speeds. As the number of Internet-of-Things (IoT) devices is exploding and the need for more aggregate wireless access capacity, VLC solutions are of high value. Because of the extensive deployment of energy-efficient Light Emitting Diodes (LEDs) for lighting and the advancements in LED technology with fast nanosecond switching times, VLC has gained a lot of interest recently. This project explored multi-element architectures in VLC systems. The multi-element VLC networks can offer increased aggregate throughput via simultaneous wireless links and attain higher spatial reuse. The downlink data transmission efficiency may be significantly improved by using multi-element VLC modules due to its light beam directionality where each LED can be modulated with different data streams.

The scientific merit of the project centered around exploring multi-element VLC designs that enable multiple mobile users to receive downlink transmissions via VLC while using legacy radio technologies for uplink transmissions. The project considered multi-LED bulb designs that can send different data streams from each LED. To transmit multiple downlink data streams simultaneously, directional light beams (i.e., a light beam that illuminates on a small area) were utilized instead of the diffused beams in traditional VLC. Providing high aggregate wireless access speeds to multiple mobile users simultaneously brings two challenges, addressed by this project. First, in order to minimize interference (or crosstalk) among multiple light beams, tuning of the directionality of the beams while making sure that an acceptable level of illumination uniformity is achieved in the room where the VLC system is operating. To tackle this challenge, the project formulated optimization problems considering several parameters such as each LED’s energy consumption, divergence angle of the light beams, and dynamic association of LEDs to mobile users in the room. Various approximation techniques and heuristic algorithms were studied to solve these problems. Second challenge arises due to the requirement of line-of-sight (LOS) between the LEDs and mobile receivers. Proper reception of VLC signals requires unbroken LOS which is hard to maintain if the receiver is mobile and the light beams are directional. Legacy high-speed VLC receivers (e.g., photodiodes or photodetectors) have small surface areas in the order of millimeter squares. Effective bandwidth of the receiver falls significantly as its active surface area increases. However, if a VLC receiver with small surface area is placed on a mobile device such as a smartphone, the LOS can be easily broken by a fingertip. To gear this challenge, the project explored VLC receiver designs with large surface areas. There exists a natural trade-off between the effective bandwidth and active surface area of the receiver. In order to handle this trade-off, the project designed sophisticated multi-stage amplification of the received signal from a single photodetector and optimal combining of the signals from an array of photodetectors. The project provided advances to multiple scientific fields that include optical wireless systems, mobile networking, wireless communication, and resource optimization. 

The VLC protocols and modules developed in this research have a great potential of implementation and deployment in a wide range of settings, including but not limited to residential and commercial buildings, and military and other high security environments. The protocols further could be included in future communication standards. The envisioned VLC technologies could be adopted by architects, designers, civil and electrical engineers in the building industry for the future carbon neutral or net-zero buildings. The broader impacts also included increasing awareness of the community in the potential for using VLC for 5G-and-beyond technologies. The project trained several graduate and undergraduate students in advanced wireless research and resulted in doctoral and master’s degrees in national priority technology areas.
